QQspd9ywxKrlPA-ae0HruQ.text: This place has a nice modern industrial fit-out combined with genuinely healthy options like cold pressed juices and quinoa and kale salad. Coffee is good and the lunch menu is quite extensive for a small place.

zTAfix5aFjhTmY_Xm-FWzQ.text: Overpriced, ridiculously slow service. Bring a book while you wait in line

HpalVtFrM7jhw39ArvOAnw.text: I came here for lunch last weekend. I had the Green Papaya salad and a matcha latte. The salad portion was very big, which is nice if you want something filling. The salad was very crunchy and I really liked the dressing- definitely made the greens in the salad pop. All in all, I enjoyed it but was not blown away by how good it was.The service was very quick and efficient.I'd definitely come back here to try something else, especially from the drinks menu, as there is quite a big selection.

photos.caption: Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom. Green papaya salad and matcha latte

4LfVsvaYqOpX2Wwj9Xo7TQ.text: Visiting London from the US. I am always scared of not being able to find healthy food to eat when I'm on a vacation. Found this place online before I left home and told myself I will have to come here at least once during my stay in London. The breakfast was tasty and healthy! I got skinny Benedict and oh boy, so glad that I could have similar breakfast to what I cook by myself everyday back home. (Okay, I'm not bragging about my cooking skill just FYI. :) ) it just sucked that it rained so hard this morning so when I arrived here, i was almost soaked. (And completely soaked when I walked back to the tube). But definitely worth the trip! :D

photos.caption: Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom. Skinny Benedict on rye

rwur9A6hVA7GZD3dvLgjWw.text: I honestly travel far and wide for a meal from The Good Life Eatery. For REAL food you can look no further. There is something for everyone, for whatever diet you're on, even if you're not on a diet, if you want to eat well and have non-healthy friends, this place is just MAGIC full stop.Fast service, lovely staff and a banging menu. I spend the majority of time trying to decide what to eat, promise myself I'll work through the menu, but end up ordering the same things cause it's just so damn good.My current favorites are The Good Life Salad - perfect for those with a sweet tooth. It's the only time I've actually really loved chowing down on kale. I also love their Raw Pad Thai and their Goodness Bowl which is a bit of everything. And all their brunches! AND THE BROWNIES . My cousin hates all this 'healthy' stuff and had one of their chia puddings I had brought home and said he'd never had something like that so good. They may be a little pricey but their portion sizes are HUGE. I also feel happy that I know they cook the food in good oils, there are no hidden nasties in the meals and sauces and genuinely makes me feel all good inside (I know I know.. But just wait Til you try it). Also, everyone who eats here is GORGEOUS so if that doesn't tell you something I don't know what will. The only negative would be the extremely small space, so if you're coming for lunch I'd try and miss prime hours (no reservations) - but it's a great place to come with a girlfriend to catch up over some yummy food! Hoping for more locations so I don't have to travel too far for a delicious meal!

photos.caption: Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom. Friendly staff
Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom. Drinks (extra stuff in fridge
Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom. Breakfast

eNy_c9UiGifpjGD6vV2TGw.text: The place has a very pretentious feel to it. The food is expensive and it doesn't do anything to justify its high price. I get the impression that it tries to "wow" you with its creative ideas and fancy presentation, but in the end, the food is lacking. Being in Chelsea, I expected it to be expensive, but 6 pounds for a small, mediocre health shake was still upsetting.The food here is healthy, as the name of the restaurant would imply, and in that regard, it's quite respectable. However, to charge a tenner for a bland waffle and some yogurt on the side is high-way robbery. Eating healthy doesn't always need to cost so much.The hype for this place through social media built up high expectations for me, but it fell somewhat flat for me.One of the more disappointing food experiences I have had in London.

22mUNS_PIoFi5r1D--hrUQ.text: It's really a good life to eat .., this place is nice they have healthy cakes , fresh juices , cold drinks and coffee .. I tried there coconut cake it's really delicious as well as there coffee .. Staff are lovely and friendly .. I was served really fast .. All in all it's an amazing place to have ur afternoon tea ..

photos.caption: Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom

B34T_Mc51EZ_GmiLs8w8Hw.text: Yum! I loved seeing so many healthy and vegan options here. I had the zucchini fettuccine and a matcha latte and both were amazing! The noodles were so yummy it you hardly notice that they are vegetables and not pasta! As far as the smoothies go, the Choc Norris is amazing!!! I highly recommend getting it. And the green smoothie called Ninja Turtle is alright, but without any fruit it's kind of bland. I've also had the acai bowl but it's not the best, and the desserts looked great too! The space is quite small, so you have to check for a table or sit at the bar next to the wall. And wifi would be a nice addition too!

photos.caption: Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom. The ninja turtle smoothie
Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom. Acai bowl to go with apple and banana on top
Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom. Matcha latte

5W9wxAgBNmOgi1HCRp5G9g.text: Review from Yana & Beca from SeeknPlay.coWhat better way to remedy a Saturday night hangover than a Sunday morning brunch trip?The Good Life Eatery was the best place to re-nourish our bodies after a few too many large glasses of wine and to clear our conscience too. The night ended with a little trip to a chicken shop... begins with K and ends with C. Oops!Healthy eating joints are popping up all over London as the health and wellness industry continues to boom. The girls behind The Good Life Eatery are taking full advantage of this #cleaneating craze and who can blame them. Yasmine and Shirin only founded The Good Life Eatery 3 years ago, the same number of restaurants they now own. This speaks passion and entrepreneurial drive. We have no doubt that more of their healthy havens will be popping up all over London.The Eatery is so popular, the long queue of people standing outside proves this, but keep an eye out or you'll walk straight past it. The cafe is welcoming and unpretentious, but fits nicely into its surroundings of the sophisticated SW3 area.  The window is full of yummy looking treats (mostly gluten free) spoiling you for choice. However, The Good Life Eatery (Sloane Avenue, Chelsea) is quite small, so be prepared to wait for a table if you're planning to eat in.Looking at the menu, you are totally spoilt for choice. We found ourselves scanning the big black boards over and over trying to decide what delicious delights to choose. Dishes are diverse and range from protein-rich smoothies, baked goods, sandwiches and superfood salads. Like two little girls in a sweet shop, we waited eagerly for our food to arrive. The time was filled sipping on our smoothie and juice drinks. Both tasted rather heavenly.Yana liberated her sweet tooth and went for the Almond and Chestnut Waffles, with Banana Mash and Chia Jam. To drink, the Choc Norris, with Raw Cacao, Almond Butter, Avocado, Banana and Almond Milk, was an obvious choice. They went down an absolute treat, in 60 seconds to be precise!After much umming and arring, Beca finally decided on the Rise and Shine granola bowl with; Chia Seed Pudding, Home-made Granola, Almond-Hazelnut Butter, Strawberry, Banana and Cranberry Powder (gluten free and dairy free). If that wasn't enough the Spelt and Quinoa Scone was thrown in there and to wash it down, a Dr Green Love juice, with Spinach, Kale, Green Apple and Coconut.Beca's thoughts: Rise and Shine was well presented and pleasing to the eye. I thoroughly enjoyed the top layer with the variety of flavours but felt a little disappointed to discover that the chia pudding dominated the bowl. Definitely not enough granola or fruit given. Being a massive scone lover I had to try The Good Eatery's Spelt and Quinoa recipe... bellissimo! Will be having that again. The chef definitely doesn't scrimp on the portion sizes, but don't worry about leaving the goodness behind. Just ask for a doggy bag! You might find the bill a little pricey, especially if you are just grabbing a quick bite to eat. We managed to spend around £13 each. The smoothies ring in at £6 a pop, but bearing in mind the location and quality of food, we let it slide.In all, we had a splendid experience at The Good Life Eatery, teaching us that there are better ways to remedy a hangover than a greasy spoon cafe! After all the food and smoothie/juices consumed we were still able to fit in a Peanut Butter Cupcake each. These little gems are rich and satisfying, and a must try if you fancy visiting The Good Life Eatery. We shall be returning!If you've been let us know your thoughts.

LJbBPus9Jtww9QjDRpTBpg.text: Good food.  Lots of gluten free savory and sweet options.  The "meatball" sandwich was very tasty, but the kale salad was so-so.  I like my kale massaged a bit to make a little more tender :)   The restaurant itself was very nice, clean.All in all, a good option if you want vegan and you're in the area.

61G97_49lutY_PvOWB-FSA.text: Good coffee... but unable to get a seat to have anything else.My hubby & I were shopping King St yesterday when we realised we hadn't had lunch and it was 3pm!  Having wanted to try out Good life eatery (mainly based on the many celebrity endorsements) for some time now, and figuring that by 3pm it might have quietened down by then, we got a quick uber over. We found a little line (about ten people ahead of us) but decided to wait it out. Firstly, the menu isn't entirely palatable to the lay man (everything is kale-something or superfood-somethingelse) but we decided to persevere and order coffees, juices and some basic grilled chicken and avocado on toast (though we nearly ordered the quinoa falafel as well).  By the time we got to the till we'd already waited about 20 mins. While my hubby paid, I asked a waitress about the seating situation. She kind of brushed me off and infered that it was every man for himself. I eyed a table that had two girls that looked like they were finishing up. After about ten mins of watching and waiting, they left and I went in for the kill, but the rude people next to that table decided to spread out across the two tables. By that point, I was over it (we'd been waiting half an hour, including queue time) so we cancelled our food order and got our coffees to go. The coffees were good,  like really good. We'd ordered iced lattes. They were strong but smooth and if I'm honest I'd queue up 15 mins for them again. Having said that I would NEVER go here in an attempt to get a table again. I find it quite annoying when cafes have tables but no table service.

MS68I-kP2S2kdMwj2pXJmg.text: Great little spot for a quick pick me up! Friendly service and up beat music. A little bit crammed but nonetheless cozy. Menu is small. Only had one dish here- but it was 5/5

photos.caption: Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom

rXngruYfCc_Zn-jnupS2Ig.text: Really fresh and really filling healthy food. I had a bowl, and was so lovely and surprises with all the extras that came on top of it, roasted toasted chickpeas, seeds, and nuts really beefed it up. The staff were so nice, friendly and helpful. Its a small spot though, if you get a table it's fine,  but if you're perched up on a stool it's not so comfortable. Biggest regret is passing on ordering some desert!

photos.caption: Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom. Goodness Bowl

u81ypz8azWhvxZLdYmlKjA.text: Consistently good food and reasonable prices for the quality. All options are creative and come with unusual flavour combinations, the products used are only top quality and feel very fresh. Pricier than your typical lunch spot but it seems worth the extra

Ox7rzH9RC_Q_Mj0LkaTniQ.text: The Good Life has some quality food and really interesting and eclectic flavor combinations. It seems apparent that they also do a fair job responsibly sourcing ingredients and delivering an aesthetically pleasing meal. So why the three star rating? Value. Small portion sizes, often bland food, and a higher than average price point make this establishment one to patron in a pinch, but not one you'd seek out and make any sort of event out of. You're not going to impress your friends with this one, but should you happen to be on the block and need a quick meal, duck in here, and you'll likely feel okay about it, if only slightly underwhelmed.

BAfm6AHjKrXpDXCg0JMJaA.text: This morning I was wandering around and came across this shop. Not being vegetarian, vegan or gluten free I was a bit worried about the food and drinks here. I decided to try the choco norris smoothie. It was so delicious and healthy tasting. I would highly recommend and will be coming back to try more things.

2x-YoCFWrKifw_3Q6Qr1nQ.text: Great place for cool hipsters :) Flour less, wheat less, dairy less yet amazing taste

photos.caption: Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom. Witty tip jar

aBOCpDf68q9mhdZilKb5eA.text: Had a teriyaki salmon bowl, the coco butter smoothie, the chocolate/avocado mousse. All 3 items were delicious, but the coco butter smoothie stole my heart. I will dream about it forever

AXUqft4SgjsiX2tKniB8Gg.text: great smoothies! the bear was the perfect mix between a green smoothie and a sweeter fruity/peanut buttery one. the oatmeal was okay but for such expensive porridge it's better to go to 26 grains in seven dials.

e3Fm9ZgsTgrQNRMuaazDuA.text: A wonderful find in London.  Small and not very many seats, but we ate at the counter and we'd do it again!   Delish salad and wrap.  Highly recommend!

4B52-HJzqlTyvq_ocEPANw.text: delicious gluten-free options here! spelt scone (low gluten) is my go-to take-awaystaff are super friendly, too! great neighborhood gem

4zoLSDD_KEZ-6FdP8p4gFg.text: This little cafe has a deliciously healthy menu! They always have a large selection of wheat and gluten free cakes (the chocolate almond cake is delicious!) and a good selection of superfood smoothies! The menu ranges from everything from eggs benedict to granola bowls, acai bowls and salads. While I love everything about the menu, I can't rave about this place for a few reasons. There are no where near enough seats. There is always a line out the door of people wanting a table and once they've ordered they stand there and eyeball you if you're at a table making you feel rushed and making it hard to enjoy your meal. If you manage to get a table before you order, you're also glared at for sitting at a table before you've ordered while the other person you're with goes to the back of the long line to order. When you get to the front of the line, staff on the cashiers are incredibly slow and don't seem to manage to get your correct order down... a little frustrating. The eggs benedict was tiny - one small piece of bread with two eggs.....and it was cold. The granola bowl was essentially a bowl of granola, with a few berries and a spoon of yogurt which definitely wasn't enough for the whole bowl.. I had the chocolate norris smoothie, which was nice but the avocado flavour seemed to be too prominent in this instance. I'm sure they're better when they're not rushed off their feet but I was really looking forward to checking this place out and I just felt harassed and rushed and then a little let down..... I'm not sure I'd be back in a hurry which is a shame as there is other items on their menu I'd have liked to try!

lgcJqJ47VlojhkB-POVj7Q.text: Probably some of the tastiest Vegetarian food that I have ever eaten. I was grateful to have a place like this right across the street from the first Airbnb that I stayed at in London. They have delicious Breakfast & Lunch items. Coffees, Teas, Smoothies, pastries etc. I'd recommend the Goodness bowl. It had a little mix of everything from tomato chickpeas, falafel balls, a variety of spiraled veggies (which I think change depending on the season).There was even a half of a whole avocado that was dipped in black sesame, sunflower & pumpkin seeds. All Served with fresh salsa. Just a really satisfying dish, and all very fresh. If I hadn't change my location in London, I definitely would have eaten here quite a few times.

z6e89gy6W9QuEq0hGV4GBA.text: A healthy place with many delicious vegan options. I had the Goodness Bowl, which they claimed is their most popular vegan menu item. It was delicious but also so huge that I couldn't finish it. It came with tomato chickpeas (my favorite part), avocado, quinoa falafels, pea/kale dip, and some salsa (I didn't like the salsa). Overall, the dish was really good, healthy, and high quality. I'm definitely going to head back here soon.

photos.caption: Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom. The Goodness Bowl made vegan...it was definitely good!

xs_92MSR1Z_JZEg8KSy3_w.text: This place rocks! A funky, narrow little place, that has a nice relaxed vibe, from both the staff and music played. I stopped by for breakfast on a Monday morning, and was able to easily get a table. The menu has a lot of great and varied options, and I finally decided on the Bel Air. Awesome. Fantastic. Tasty. Cooked right. Nothing annoys me more than poorly done Poached Eggs, and so when they arrived cooked to perfection I was already sold. The fritter was extremely tasty (not the sort of thing I'd ordinarily choose) and upon completion of the meal my taste buds and belly were fully satiated. The best thing - the coffee didn't disappoint!! Right temperature and right flavour! This was a great find.

2z_Zk-KqxplNAJbyNvka5A.text: This is a small cafe type eatery that is equally a coffee shop and restaurant.  They serve several healthy options, including vegan and gluten free.  Small seating area, but it wasn't busy at lunch hour and the service was fast.  You order at the counter, take a number, and someone will bring it to you. I had the good life salad, which was OK, minus the lack in flavor and the fact that it included raw kale, which isn't its best uncooked in some way.  I also tried the quinoa scone, which was decent.  Nonetheless, I would give this place another go.

qSvYvC0-r_mIsPk5mViExA.text: This reminded me of a modern California breakfast nook. Healthy and tasty. Good bowls and benis. And all the classic coffee drinks you need to go with it. Earned this Californian's approval!

4qTjTp7ehZkbPfF4ykB_Hw.text: Using an UberEats voucher we recently ordered our dinner from Good Life Eatery delivered to St James Park.I'd never heard of GLE (although there are 3 in close proximity to where I live) and without the voucher wouldn't have ordered it as the salads are pretty expensive however they sounded so good and we had discount so we went for it.I was so impressed the flavours, quality of food and portion size. They were blooming massive! We went for the feta and tomato courgetti and the hot chicken with refried beans and rice. We also ordered a delicious coconut milk based smoothie with berries. The hot food arrived still hot (something I have had issues with in recent deliveries) and the portions really were so big we were able to both have it for lunch the next day. Highlights definitely include the smoothie and the hot dish - the chicken was so moist and the rice and beans full of flavour. The courgetti was also really good but got a bit samey quite quickly. There are tonnes more scrummy sounding salads as well as a brunch menu which looks fab - will definitely be either visiting or ordering from them again soon.

photos.caption: Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom

G8Gofr5tDzdaqJ-WCvoaLQ.text: This place is way too hyped up on Instagram.The food was good but I experienced serious food/meal envy with my girlfriend. I ordered The Lean Machine bowl with sweet potato falafel and the Ninja Turtle (veggie/green) smoothie. I was slightly disappointed with both. The bowl was okay but nothing in comparison with the teriyaki salmon Man Bowl. The smoothly wasn't great (even though it's supposedly a favourite). It tasted of water and cucumber, only much thicker and I didn't finish it. The Berry Sunrise was decent though and I would consider getting it again (even though it was £6 per smoothly)! By the way, don't be put off by the name "Man Bowl"... a woman can eat this easy and it's worth getting.The restaurant looked nice - it has a rustic, healthy, modern twist going for it. The downside is that it's way too small and busy. We did go on a Saturday so it might be worth trying on a weekday instead. There were no tables available when we arrive so we sat at a bar overlooking the stairs to the bathroom. Also, we felt way to close to everyone to properly enjoy the meal and left the restaurant feeling slightly overwhelmed. I honestly think the restaurant could be massively improved if they remove the bars and let fewer customers eat in at a time.The service was also quite strange. We were given two options as to how we could wait for a table. We ended up sitting at a bar to eat until a table was made available. Even when a table was freed up, we decided not to move because you could tell everyone was waiting for a table (there were a lot of people waiting) and we didn't want to race to it. It would be nice if the staff organised this.

photos.caption: Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom. Smoothies
Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom. Smoothies and bowls
Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom. Smoothly menu. Berry Sunrise is good. Ninja Turtle is not.

PW-2faaDpmG9V516R_U9Ew.text: I've been to The Good Life Eatery a few times now, and I've been solidly happy with my meal each time. It's a very health-food oriented place, with plenty of options for veggies and meat-eaters alike. The till is almost overwhelming with the amount of treats and juices there are to choose from (and then there's the actual menu), but the back is a calm space with plenty of two-person seating.For breakfast, I tried the açai bowl and one of their mylk drinks. The açai was nice, and topped with plenty of fruits and granola. I wasn't so much a fan of the mylk, but I think that was more of a texture thing than anything else. When I came back for lunch, I ordered their daily soup (cauliflower - amazing!) and a slice of avo toast, which was nothing special in comparison. I also tried the green juice and a sip of my boyfriend's coconut water, which was exquisitely fresh because of the literal slice of coconut in the bottle. He also ordered a Man Bowl (of course) and ate all of it before I could try any, so that's a ringing endorsement.All of that being said, the conclusion I've drawn from my experiences at The Good Life Eatery is that in order to enjoy said good life, you've gotta be willing to pay the price. Which is hella expensive.

photos.caption: Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom. Cauliflower soup and avo toast.

KVVSSJxqRFkXWSZQ9zrq_g.text: I had such high hopes for this place.  My husband and I went on a Saturday and it was packed so the wait was quite long.  The coffee I must say is delicious, I got an almond latte and he got a normal coffee but the quality was superb.  We didn't get our food until 30 minutes after we sat down which is unusually long for breakfast foods.  For our meals we got eggs benedict and a waffle, needless to say the eggs on the benedict was completely overcooked as if it were two hard boiled eggs.  They were so packed that it was impossible to get anyones attention.  The waffles were good but the overall experience was kind of a bust, everyone in the restaurant was angry and looking for a waiting and most people seemed displeased by the quality of food.

QCe4JkZ0RpUj058QehNXdg.text: The hubs and me were in London for five days and we ate breakfast here three times. Super fresh and healthy food. The chili avocado toast was my favorite, made with a tasty hearty whole grain bread. The egg yolks are bright orange - quite unlike most of our eggs in the US. Very friendly vibe.

WOojaL-GFY11sT1kXV5MOA.text: This place is on Deliveroo, and they really do not deliver. We ordered four dishes and only received one of them. When calling them up to get the rest they said they would send the rest of our food, but then just cancelled because they were closing. I'm still hungry. Who sends someone the extra avocado in a salad, but leaves out the salad? Would give 0 starts if I could.

xXYXgItxr5hZ-6PTILKbOQ.text: I'm not one who seeks out only " healthy" options , however have eaten here twice for breakfast and the food both times was excellent . Had the carrot and turmeric fritters ( Bel Air Brekkie) one time and the Skinny Benedict ( poached eggs on smashed avo and cherry tomatoes , charcoal sourdough bread) the other time . My partners dishes were also very good and they do good coffee . Recommended .

Evn2_O-JNHMOdy0BrjR__g.text: Thought we would try it after reading the great reviews. Service was not very friendly at all, poached eggs were cold, portion small and presentation average.

WUmHi-MyxAHp-uEgedhX0A.text: The place looks like it is healthy... and I think it is! The toasted sandwich was really good (you can even choose your bread) but ordering in addition a smoothie and a carrot cake was not a smart idea. Was far too much for one person! The frosting on top of the cake was a bit too sweet for my taste but I would still love to go again to try out the other dishes.

photos.caption: Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom

JiOxeupynFO9FsPMcOVKQg.text: The Good Life Eatery is an AMAZING find- the food here is beyond fresh and delicious, and it's one of the only restaurants I can eat at where I don't leave feeling weighed down or guilty about my food. Definitely come give this pace a shot if you are interested in healthy/clean eating!

CQCyqHy4FjQ2v4gG8Yuitg.text: We went to the Knightbridge location and it was amazing ! Nice place to have a healthy and good brunch with friends. The prices are high but the quality is really good. I ordered a "Rio Deal" smoothie. Really good and fulfill! Then with a friend we shared a "so fresh and so clean" bowl and a "open-faced salmon avocado". It didn't seem that big at a glance but after eating it we were really full! I totally recommend that place for a healthier version the Sunday brunch than the typical English one !

photos.caption: Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom. "So fresh and so clean" bowl and "open faced salmon avocado" sandwich
Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom. "Rio Deal" and "Ninja Turtle" smoothies

sYr4tQakQhIOTiyg8sc_7A.text: This review is for the Knightsbridge location. I got takeaway food here last Monday and was very happy with my options although I think a part of my orders were botched. I got the GOODNESS BOWL:  hollywood tabbouleh, zucchini fettucine, sweet potato, quinoa, falafel, black bean dip, gluten free crackers,  1/2 avocado with omega seeds, red pepper chilli sauce GF for £12.50; the THE GOOD LIFE SALAD with kale, roasted sweet potato, quinoa, lentils, walnut, goji berries, nutritional yeast and orange tahini vinaigrette GF V for £11.00; the BAKED SWEET POTATO & QUINOA FALAFEL GF DF with basil cashew cream GF Vfor £4.50; the PEANUT BUTTER CUPS (Organic Peanut Butter, Spelt, Cocoa, Non-Hydrogenated Sunflower Spread (3 Pieces) for £3.75; and last but not least an energy ball. Leftovers for days!I thought the Goodness Bowl was the better of the two salads as the sweet potato mash is delicious: incredibly creamy with roasted overtones. The avocado was perfectly creamy with the omega seeds a nice crunchy addition and the sauce tangy and tasty. However, I seemed to be missing the black bean dip =/. The portion though large, far more so than the Good Life salad. The Good Life salad had great nuggets of sweet potato but the kale was dry. I did ask for dressing on the side though so it's likely my fault. I assumed though the kale would be massaged to break up the plant's naturally tough fibers. The dressing was marvelous though.The falafel was crunchy but I admit I didn't taste sweet potato very much. Sadly, I didn't get the basil cashew cream that was supposed to accompany it. The PB cup was definitely "healthy" tasting; don't be fooled you'e getting a Reese's. But I love anything PB so was up my alley. It has a crumbly texture.I'm dinking a star just because of the missing sauce and the fact it's so expensive!!

sZZjBv_7krfqXm-uIHropg.text: It's a good life when you can eat bloody good food! And this were the Good Life Eatery come in place. I originally found out about them through Ella Woodward "Deliciously Ella" where she recommends good health places to dine at. Plus God was pointing at it too and also I recently borrowed "The Good Life Eatery Cookbook" so that was the final push for me. I had to attend. Upon arrival the cakes were displayed in the window and my eyes were drawn to the Red velvet cake. God knows I love me some Red velvet ever since Hummingbird bakery introduced London to its deliciousness. So I ordered at the counter my Red velvet slice for £4 made only with Gluten free ingredients and also Dairy free. I also ordered a Matcha Latte which you can choose what milk you want at no extra cost. I chose Almond milk. The cake  was perfectly moist with light cream cheese which I felt you could tell the different from the normal one. Unfornately I would of loved if they had used alternative sweeteners instead of caster sugar. The Matcha Latte was nice and light especially great on a humid day. It is a small place with know downstairs beside the toilet, kitchen and office.  I came on a late Sunday afternoon on the hottest day of the year so far and it was a chilled out vibe. Absolutely love the decor, topical plant, overhead fan, barstools, lovely chest nutty brown furniture. I like the fact their was a jug of water and a few magazines including their cookbook for your leisure.  They don't have free WIFi because they would prefer that people speak to each other or just be! Which I think is great it nice to be mindful and enjoy the simple thing in life like the pleasure of eating great food. I'm sooooo coming back to try their food, which look A-MA-ZING!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom. Red velvet cake with Matcha Latte.
Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Good Life Eatery - London, United Kingdom

Y7ecWEqjuMSLvznEdRQgoQ.text: The food is very good here and imaginative. However I really don't like the coffee - it has an unpleasant metallic taste to it. But the real killer is no wifi. I cannot understand how any cafe, let alone an ultra premium one, can be so customer unfriendly.

F4X9chNYOlIDQ6wlJ7nIgA.text: Great food and great coffee! We were staying in the neighborhood for the week and ate here multiple mornings. Avocado toast is fabulous with a poached egg. Everyone who works here is super nice too!
